Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Generalized Geometry, String Theory and Deformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a multi-institutional (Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effort to study the mathematical theory of generalized geometries and its applications to string theory. Generalized geometries form a class of almost complex manifolds with reduced structure groups, which have become of central importance to the study of realistic string theory models. These are natural generalizations of Calabi-Yau manifolds and are of mathematical interest in their own right. In one class important for string theory, the canonical structure one seeks on a generalized Calabi-Yau manifold is governed by a fully nonlinear complex Monge Ampere type system that couples a balanced Hermitian metric to an anti self-dual connection of a vector bundle. When the manifold is Kahler Calabi-Yau and the vector bundle is the tangent bundle, this system reduces to the Calabi conjecture for Ricci-flat metrics. Generalized geometries arise as the internal component of spacetime of string theory models that are much closer to our real world than previous constructions. The mathematics that governs such a geometry is a natural extension of deep problems in geometric analysis, algebraic geometry, and deformation theory. The physics that is behind the new geometry provides inspiration and novel approaches to posing and solving the mathematical problems. Their solutions will in turn lead to greater understanding of fundamental problems in physics, making this a truly interdisciplinary collaboration.

The mathematical understanding of generalized geometries is still in its nascent stage. The purpose of this proposal is to develop this field further, into a full-fledged extension of Kahler Calabi-Yau geometries. We will focus on the following tightly interconnected problems: constructing new solutions to string theory in this class; characterizing deformations and specifically the moduli of these spaces; computing the dimension of the space's light fields; and an understanding of "generalized calibrations" - the analog of calibrated submanifolds of special holonomy manifolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a multi-institutional (Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effort to study the mathematical theory of generalized geometries and deformations, as well as its applications to string theory.


Generalized geometries form a class of almost complex manifolds with reduced structure groups, which have becomeof central importance to the study of realistic string theory models. These are natural generalizations of Calabi-Yau manifolds and are of mathematical interest in their own right. In one class important for string theory, the canonical structure one seeks on a generalized Calabi-Yau manifold is governed by a fully nonlinear complex Monge-Ampere type system that couples a balanced Hermitian metric to an anti self-dual connection of a vector bundle. When the manifold is Kahler Calabi-Yau and the vector bundle is the tangent bundle, this system reduces to the Calabi conjecture for Ricci-flat metrics.The mathematical understanding of generalized geometries is still in its nascent stage.  The purpose of this proposal was to develop this field further, extending Kahler Calabi-Yau geometries. In this project, we have studied the followingtightly interconnected problems: constructing new solutions to string theory in this class; characterizing  deformations andspecifically the moduli of these spaces; computing the dimension of the space light fields; an understanding of "generalized calibrations"; constructing differential systems that govern deformations of these geometries; and understanding solutions to these  systems. Many new results of this project have been obtained and reported in these directions including: new understanding of monodromy problems, degenerations and deformations of CY varieties; new insights on the relationship between topological string theory and knot theory; and a novel topological and physical interpretation of a large class of special functions.

This project was a joint effort between mathematicians and physicists with diverse expertise to explore a new frontier in geometry. A generalized geometry arises as a component of spacetime for building string theory models that are much closer to our natural world than previous attempts. The mathematics that governs such a geometry is also a natural extension of deep problems in geometric analysis and deformation theory. The physics that is behind the new geometry provides inspiration and novel approaches to posing and solving the mathematical problems. Their solutions will in turn lead to greater understanding of fundamental problems in physics, making this a truly interdisciplinary collaboration.
